texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This problem came up in conversation earlier this week and I realized that I'd never written a post about it. Has this ever happened to you before?
texts.text: This problem came up in conversation earlier this week and I realized that I'd never written a post about it. Has this ever happened to you before?

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ ssh -YC remotebox
[major@remotebox ~]$ xterm
xterm: Xt error: Can't open display:
xterm: DISPLAY is not set
texts.text:
$ ssh -YC remotebox
[major@remotebox ~]$ xterm
xterm: Xt error: Can't open display:
xterm: DISPLAY is not set

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've scratched my head on this error message when the remote server is a minimally-installed CentOS, Fedora, or Red Hat system. It turns out that the  xorg-x11-xauth  package wasn't installed with the minimal package set and I didn't have any  authentication credentials ready  to hand off to the X server on the remote machine.
texts.text: I've scratched my head on this error message when the remote server is a minimally-installed CentOS, Fedora, or Red Hat system. It turns out that the  xorg-x11-xauth  package wasn't installed with the minimal package set and I didn't have any  authentication credentials ready  to hand off to the X server on the remote machine.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Luckily, the fix is a quick one:
texts.text: Luckily, the fix is a quick one:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Close the ssh connection to your remote server and give it another try:
texts.text: Close the ssh connection to your remote server and give it another try:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You should now have an xterm from the remote machine on your local computer.
texts.text: You should now have an xterm from the remote machine on your local computer.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The source of the problem is that you don't have a MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE on the remote system. The  Xsecurity  man page explains it fairly well:
texts.text: The source of the problem is that you don't have a MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE on the remote system. The  Xsecurity  man page explains it fairly well:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When using MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1, the client sends a 128 bit "cookie" along with the connection setup information. If the cookie presented by the client matches one that the X server has, the connection is allowed access. The cookie is chosen so that it is hard to guess; xdm generates such cookies automatically when this form of access control is used. The user's copy of the cookie is usually stored in the .Xauthority file in the home directory, although the environment variable XAUTHORITY can be used to specify an alternate location. Xdm automatically passes a cookie to the server for each new login session, and stores the cookie in the user file at login.
texts.text: When using MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1, the client sends a 128 bit "cookie" along with the connection setup information. If the cookie presented by the client matches one that the X server has, the connection is allowed access. The cookie is chosen so that it is hard to guess; xdm generates such cookies automatically when this form of access control is used. The user's copy of the cookie is usually stored in the .Xauthority file in the home directory, although the environment variable XAUTHORITY can be used to specify an alternate location. Xdm automatically passes a cookie to the server for each new login session, and stores the cookie in the user file at login.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Your home directory on the remote server should have a small file called  .Xauthority  with the magic cookie in binary:
texts.text: Your home directory on the remote server should have a small file called  .Xauthority  with the magic cookie in binary:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[major@remotebox ~]$ ls -al ~/.Xauthority
-rw-------. 1 major major 61 Jul 14 19:28 /home/major/.Xauthority
[major@remotebox ~]$ file ~/.Xauthority
/home/major/.Xauthority: data
texts.text:
[major@remotebox ~]$ ls -al ~/.Xauthority
-rw-------. 1 major major 61 Jul 14 19:28 /home/major/.Xauthority
[major@remotebox ~]$ file ~/.Xauthority
/home/major/.Xauthority: data
